summary: This document is an email chain from March 2016, forwarded in February 2019, discussing a meeting request to discuss a potential sex trafficking case against Jeffrey Epstein. The initial email, from a U.S. Attorney's Office official, describes a pitch from lawyers representing a victim and outlines the complex legal background, including Epstein's 2007 non-prosecution agreement.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Described as a financier with multiple homes, accused of sex trafficking with dozens of victims, including a 16-year-old, and subject of a 2007 non-prosecution agreement with the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida.

persons.name: Pete Skinner
persons.context: One of the lawyers who, along with two others, pitched a sex trafficking case against Jeffrey Epstein to the U.S. Attorney's Office.

connections.description: Skinner, as a lawyer, pitched a sex trafficking case against Epstein on behalf of a victim.

events.title: Epstein's non-prosecution agreement
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein entered into a non-prosecution agreement with the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida.

events.title: Meeting request to discuss Epstein case
events.description: A U.S. Attorney's Office official emails colleagues to schedule a meeting to discuss a potential sex trafficking case against Jeffrey Epstein, based on a pitch from lawyers.

keyFacts: In March 2016, lawyers including Pete Skinner pitched a sex trafficking case against Jeffrey Epstein to the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York.
The case involved a victim who claims to have been prostituted by Epstein at age 16, with Epstein alleged to have had dozens of victims.
The email notes Epstein's 2007 non-prosecution agreement with the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida as a complicating legal factor.
The document indicates ongoing interest and investigation into Epstein's conduct by federal prosecutors in New York as of 2016.
